title: Hot Tables
name: Hot Tables
description:
A Map by Baostar

The best places to eat around the globe.

properties.name: Alto
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 520 Madison Ave, New York, NY 10022At his latest Midtown restaurant, a stylish, quiet, gray space tucked behind a slab of the Berlin Wall, Scott Conant introduces the food and wines of the Alto Adige, a mountainous area in northern Italy, across the border from Austria. His cooking is sensual and refined, beginning with a delicate crudo of sea scallops, yellowtail with sea urchin and caviar sauce, and smoked trout with parsley root vinaigrette. Pastas include miniature agnolotti in a Parmesan foam, and tagliatelle in a rich goose ragoût; flavored with stewed prunes. The suckling pig comes with airy semolina gnocchi and bitter greens, the pike with spaetzle, and the guinea hen (poached breast, roasted leg) with sauerkraut, speck, and a foie gras emulsion. The wonderful Austrian desserts include rhubarb strudel with roasted strawberries and Sacher torte with kumquat marmalade (prix fixe, 5–15).

properties.name: Island Prime
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 880 Harbor Island Dr., San Diego, CaliforniaDeborah Scott revolutionized the San Diego dining scene with Kemo Sabe and Indigo Grill, and her latest venture proves that the celebrity chef still has the touch. Combining a stunning waterfront setting—a spacious dining room hovers over the bay and a more casual outdoor deck has fantastic waterfront views—with a hip and sometimes humorous take on the surf-and-turf joints that Scott grew up with in her native Virginia, Island Prime blows everything else along the shoreline clean out of the water. The menu ranges from traditional filet mignon and old-school linguine and clams to offbeat signature Scott dishes such as nut-crusted Brie with honey-roasted garlic and jalapeño jelly. The sides are equally scrumptious—especially the crunchy corn and the baby beets (entrées, 3–8).

properties.name: Pizzaiolo
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 5008 Telegraph Ave., Oakland, CaliforniaPizzaiolo is the best eatery to open in Oakland\'s Temescal neighborhood, which has lately emerged as the southern counterpart to North Berkeley\'s Gourmet Ghetto. If Charlie Hallowell, an eight-year veteran of Chez Panisse, served his thin-crust Neapolitan-style pizzas in a truck stop, there\'d still be a line. But add a hot locale and stylish decor—Hallowell designed the interior himself, teaming up with his father-in-law to construct tables and benches from 120-year-old reclaimed Douglas fir and exposing some of the original brick—and the wait to be seated usually lasts an hour. Not than anyone\'s complaining. His pizzas, artfully scattered with innovative toppings (think arugula salad or truffled brandade), emerge from the 750-degree wood-burning oven blackened at the edges and perfectly chewy. Non-pizza dishes—such as farro with shrimp, arugula, and tomatoes; pork with polenta and broccoli rabe; and clams with homemade sausage, chickpeas, and kale—are equally impressive (entrées, 0–8).

properties.name: Quince
properties.description: Posted by Edbogus 1701 Octavia St, San Francisco,"This is no place for someone living paycheck to paycheck. In one of San Francisco\'s most fashionable residential neighborhoods, the small, smart eatery caters to folks with fat pocketbooks who plan ahead: tables are booked weeks in advance. Michael Tusk, who has cooked at the legendary Chez Panisse and Oliveto, oversees the kitchen. The menu, which changes daily and marries French, Italian, and American traditions, includes such inviting -- and delicious -- dishes as fresh pasta with scallops, duck breast and leg confit, wild nettle sformato (Italian-style custard), and more. The wine list is top-notch but pricey, and the service is both professional and friendly. Reservations essential." Fodor\'s Travel Wire
